comments.commentBody: Anyone who has ever paid any attention to Trump shouldn't be fooled by this fakery.
There is a video where Ted attempts to hug the older daughter, her negative body language was far from welcoming of his attempted affection.

Actually, erm … I, though a Democrat, watched all three of these Republican family town halls, and am utterly embarrassed to say that I was impressed by the Trump family. I don't know what I was expecting, but I kept having to tamp down the response "well, he must not be as terrible as I thought, they seemed to have turned out fine." A family, in a "Dallas" or "Dynasty" kind of way. Well-prepared, but affable. Plus there was a moment when Trump and Melania exchanged a smile that felt like the brief, passing public intimacy of a real couple.

And the Kasichs: Mrs. Kasich reminded me of several go-get-'em Midwestern moms I encountered during my daughter's public-school years. The two girls were annoyingly/refreshingly normal (annoying in saying "like" every other word, as my own did at that age) and not smothered by coaching. Didn't seem like a perpetual power struggle going on. Neither Trump nor Kasich dominated or overshadowed their families.

But the Cruz family: ick! I still haven't had enough showers to wash away this image: "we have something of a game where to get a hug and kiss from the girls, I usually have to do about four laps chasing them in the living room. And one will go one way and one will go the other way, and I have to tackle them. They usually get their good night hugs hanging upside down by their feet. And it's -- we have fun." Said in his nasally reptilian way. It all felt cold and rehearsed to death, with Ted being controlling and dominant.

It seems we need standards for what constitutes a study and what gets published.
I always felt the same with the chocolate studies. Dark chocolate good milk chocolate bad. The problem is they never studied milk chocolate. There was no causative or correlative factors to make a determination about milk chocolate.

This diversion to how poorly African Americans would have fared had they remained in Africa is so old. How would you have fared had your forbears remained in Ireland (famine) or eastern Europe (war, poverty) or wherever the hell your ancestors came crawling from?

The Jews were enslaved in Egypt. Was that a good thing?

Let's deal with the facts: black people were brought here in chains and treated as property. All of Christianity -- if you are a believer - says something about reparations.

Indeed Germany compensated the Jews for the holocaust as did the US the Japanese for internment camps. If black lives mattered, those who wronged them would have made amends. And certainly no one with a decent bone in their body would write what you did.

Shame on you and all who recommended your post.
And you read the article, didn't you?

"The liberal media and Fox News just can’t quit the demagogue" says the sub-heading.

And it seems that you can't either, Ross.

"Yes it costs more, but so what? If cost is a concern, not eating any animal products is the lowest cost (and kindest) solution."

Not for the working poor. Not everyone has the time to travel around to boutique farms to pick up seasonal greens and unfertilized eggs. With four kids in my household and parents working two jobs each, the luxury of asking about how much space Collin the Chicken has at the elusive Aliki's farm is non-existant.

True, but dairy is also an extremely cruel industry and involves lots of killing.

http://milkiscruel.com/

Pretending otherwise only hurts.

Interestingly enough, India is the single largest exporter of red meat in the world http://money.cnn.com/2015/08/05/news/economy/india-beef-exports-buffalo/

Also, the Buddha did not ban the consumption of meat. His rules for the monastic community, the Vinaya, contains 227 rules of conduct for the monks. Some of them address manners in eating, but none of them forbid the consumption of meat.

If the concern is to push for food that causes less harm to everyone, human, animal and bird, there is little option other than educating the public on the merits of vegetarianism.

In fact we Hindus strongly believe that the human feelings and whole nature becomes blunted by association with butchering of animals and people will find it extremely difficult to govern animal passion violent nature and restless condition. It is for this very reason vegetarianism is strongly linked with Indic religions that originated in ancient India.

Indic religious (Jainism, Hinduism and Buddhism) philosophical schools forbid consumption of meat and Jainism institutes an outright ban on the same. Consequently, India is home to more vegetarians than any other country. About 30% of India's 1.2 billion population practices lacto vegetarianism.

Every act by which a person directly or indirectly supports killing or injury is seen as violence, which creates harmful karma, a spiritual principle of cause and effect where intent and actions of an individual (cause) influence the future of that individual (effect). The aim of ahimsa is to prevent the accumulation of such karma.

Jains consider nonviolence to be the most essential religious duty for everyone. Their scrupulous and thorough way of applying nonviolence to everyday activities, and especially to food, shapes their entire lives and is the most significant hallmark of Jain identity.

Leapy,

Note that the dictionary draws the distinction between a phalanx of soldiers, which may not be called a phalange, and the bone, which may. I pointed out that this usage is listed in the MW11 (desk encyclopedia) precisely because that means the compilers feel the usage is current, and not historical. For a word to make the abridgment cut it cannot be obsolete or too obscure.

You need to find all the people who call a finger bone a phalange (none of whom are around here), get them to stop and get them to write Mr. Merriam and Mr. Webster and confirm they've atoned.

Martin, I can't think how often I've heard "Oh, I don't have a fracture; the ER doc said it's just broken". In all those cases, I felt the only important thing was that the patienst knew all they needed about the injury and got the proper treatment, and not that they hew to my nomenclature. I still can't absorb that enough people say 'phalange' to make it into M-W, but I guess if if can come to terms with the inappropriate 'apropos', I can get to where 'phalange' don't gnaw at me.

PS: Back in 2012, you just rebutted with an article en francais; howcum you never mentioned M-W till now?

Leapy,

Sorry. I'm lucky to remember yesterday's dinner. I'm afraid those 2012 synapses have been repurposed for more important duty, like Elaine's birthday.

Speaking of which, Alex forgot her birthday a little over a week ago. I defied Elaine and dropped a few hints after the fact. Clearly they were too subtle. I ratcheted up the obviousness until one email that mentioned the date, the dinner, the champagne finally hit home.

Of course he freaked and tried to send her flowers. I got a call from a florist who said he was trying to deliver flowers to Elaine but the hospital said she's been discharged so could I pick them up? I love Elaine dearly but declined to get involved in what was clearly an episode of "Dumb and Dumber." Last I heard, Alex, FTD, the florist and some hospital were pointing fingers at each other and she never did get the flowers.

(Yesterday's thread is already very long.)
Continuing, re: PHALANGE.

Leapy and David,

What exactly is you point? You would reject a puzzle because it uses a word that dictionaries accept -- even the abridged M-W desk dictionary, http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/phalange -- and has been used by Margaret Farrar as well as Will Shortz?

If a clue had "phalange," it would be a no-brainer to change it the preferable "phalanx." But we're not talking about a clue. An entry means rewriting, or deep-sixing, the puzzle. Why? Because the word is a back-formation from the plural that's only been used for 350 years?

I don't say "phalange." I don't say "bicep" (which irks me even more). But other people do, and have for a long time. It's a word and I don't see why an entire puzzle should be shot because it used it.
Steamed oysters ARE delicious and yes, the plump ones are a must!  Butter with vermouth and pimenton?  Sounds good to me!

In Asian markets they sell these giant oysters that are 3 or 4 inches long that go great steamed with a dipping sauce of soy sauces, chopped scallions and coriander.  You can also add some chopped chiles to the sauce.
The oysters that begin with an "s" are likely Sewansecotts from the H.M. Terry Co., Willis Wharf, VA. on the Eastern Shore. They are the best!

Where have you been? We are The Oyster Bar Columbia and have been steaming oysters for 15 years. Only way we serve them other than raw. This is not a new idea. It is just the way it is done down south!

And here is the marker for a generation: "Recently, I have noticed that my children, all in their 30s now, want tradition, but they also want natural, sustainable and flavorful. Most important, they don’t want the smell of fish stock in the kitchen." Let's name upper middle-class people in their thirties the Oxymoron Generation. Euuuuuuu. And I'm not reacting to the smell of fish stock cooking.
My Hungarian Jewish grandmother, an amazing cook, disliked the smell of gefilte fish cooking.  She always made falsche fish using veal.  It was delicious! Unfortunately, I don't have the recipe.
And that's what the trendies are: trendies.

For some reason my copy of the article didn't contain any mention of the halvah donuts from Underwest Donuts at 638 West 47th St
New York NY. Must have been an error in transmission.
My grandmother used to give us, her grandchildren, halvah in lieu of chocolate bars back in the late '50s, early '60s. Hated it.

I've always loved halvah and those little rectangular sesame crunch candies.
Even Haagen Daz has a toasted sesame brittle ice cream, I'm on my second pint!
http://www.haagendazs.us/products/4059/ice-cream/toasted-sesame-brittle/
SESAME CRUNCH!----------Very sweet (sesame seeds, honey & perhaps cane sugar), but one such candy left to melt in the mouth, while taking sips of hot, black tea, can be quite comforting.

Umm, yes, enticingly green in some cases. But I once had a back yard full of enticingly purple spears of asparagus. Big, fat, and delicious.  Had to give them up when I went to the woods. But the upshot is yes, cut the shoots when they are coming up early. And enjoy when you can.
I order 5 cases,27# eat a 1/3, blanch and freeze,(Vacuum seal) 2/3, and we have AMAZING Asparagus year round, we adore asparagus
"Everything old is new again".  Do not worry about traditions or critics, just make the best wine you can.
Why not both: history of wineries & lessons? I find both to be entertaining & educational.

David B. Benson, 15 April post

Dear Mr. Benson,

Interesting information; thanks for sharing it with us.

There is a massive array of wind turbines southeast of Kingfisher, Oklahoma. I go by there now and then.

On Christmas Day, about 10:30a.m., I cruised by and saw that none of the turbine blades were turning.

Not enough wind.

I went by yesterday, again about 10:30 a.m. That day there was a lot of wind, probably 15-20 mph, gusting 25 perhaps. Not unusual for an April day in Oklahoma. The "wind comes sweepin' down the plains", as the song says, quite a bit in these parts.

None of the turbine blades were turning. They were feathered.

Too much wind.

So I guess wind turbines will make power but there mustn't be too much wind, and there mustn't be too little.

Sort of a Goldilocks technology.

Makes me wonder if wind power is really ready to serve as the primary motive force for an advanced industrial civilization.
not over rated. over pitched!
Matt Harvey is overrated!
I have a 24" wide counter depth fridge and stove, both by Blomberg, a German brand.  They are the perfect size for our small family with dinner guests a few nights a week.
